evidence.source_document: Order Granting Plaintiffs’ Motion for Class Certification
evidence.text: the motion for class certification is GRANTED.

extracted.value: Granted Plaintiffs’ Motion for Class Certification on July 17, 2019, certifying a class of individuals who have been issued predicate Special Immigrant Juvenile Status orders by Washington state courts after turning eighteen years old but prior to turning twenty-one years old and have submitted or will submit SIJS petitions to USCIS prior to turning twenty-one years old.

evidence.source_document: Order Granting Plaintiffs’ Motion for Summary Judgment and Permanent Injunction
evidence.text: Plaintiffs are entitled to summary judgment in their favor regarding the unlawfulness of the reunification requirement and the unreasonable delays in adjudicating SIJ petitions.

extracted.value: Granted Plaintiffs’ Motion for Summary Judgment and Permanent Injunction on October 5, 2020, finding USCIS's reunification requirement arbitrary and capricious and unlawful delays in adjudicating SIJ petitions violated the 180-day statutory deadline.

evidence.source_document: Order Granting Plaintiffs’ Motion for Preliminary Injunction
evidence.text: Plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunction is GRANTED. In light of the Court’s order certifying a class, it is hereby ORDERED that defendants and their officers, agents, employees, representatives, and all persons acting in concert or participating with them are ENJOINED AND RESTRAINED: ● from denying Special Immigrant Juvenile Status pursuant to 8 U.S.C. §1101(a)(27)(J) on the ground that a Washington state court does not have jurisdiction or authority to 'reunify' an immigrant with his or her parents

extracted.value: Granted Plaintiffs’ Motion for Preliminary Injunction on July 17, 2019, enjoining defendants from enforcing the 2018 policy that denied SIJ status due to lack of state court jurisdiction to reunify juveniles with parents.

evidence.text: We therefore hold that the district court abused its discretion because the record does not support the reasonableness of the district court’s order that broadly permits each and every SIJ petitioner to 'toll' indefinitely Congress’s timeline for adjudicating SIJ petitions, without apparent consideration of existing regulations, without an affirmative showing of good cause specific to each class member’s claim for tolling, when the district court held USCIS strictly accountable to the statutory deadline, and where 8 U.S.C. § 1232(d)(2) plainly provides no mechanism for 'tolling.' On remand, the district court may consider amending its injunction to allow tolling on a case-by-case basis, upon an affirmative showing of good cause, subject to a definite limitation on the tolling duration.

We AFFIRM the district court’s issuance of injunctive relief; we VACATE only the provision of the district court’s permanent injunction that permits SIJ petitioners (but not the Government) to 'toll' Congress’s deadline for adjudicating SIJ petitions; and we REMAND to the district court to make any further, proper modifications to its order consistent with this disposition.

extracted.value: Appellate court affirmed district court's issuance of permanent injunction requiring USCIS to adjudicate SIJ petitions within 180 days, but vacated the provision allowing SIJ petitioners to 'toll' the statutory deadline indefinitely without showing good cause, and remanded for modification to allow case-by-case tolling with good cause and time limits.
